1090410.1007/10904.1574-1451Journal of Inorganic and Organometallic Polymers and MaterialsJ Inorg Organomet Polym1574-14431574-1451Springer USBostons10904-011-9552-0955210.1007/s10904-011-9552-0CommunicationHydrothermal Synthesis, Characterization of Mn(II) and Cd(II) Coordination Polymers Assembled from Semi-Rigid Oxo-Bridged Carboxylate and N-Donor LigandsYuLing-Ling1aDepartment of Biology Chemistry EngineeringWeihai Vocational College264210WeihaiShandongChinawhyull@yeah.net5820111201222127828216720119420111672011582011© Springer Science+Business Media, LLC 20112011Abstract

Two new metal–organic coordination polymers containing Mn(II) and Cd(II) with oxo-bridged and N-donor ligands, [Mn(oba)(2,2′-bipy)]n (1) and {[Cd(oba)(bib)]·H2O}n (2) [2,3′-H2oba = 2-(3-carboxyphenoxy)benzoic acid, 2,2′-bipy = 2,2′-bipyridine, and bib = 4,4′-bis(2-methylimidazole-1-ylmethyl)biphenyl], have been prepared and characterized by elemental analysis, Fourier infrared spectroscopy, and X-ray diffraction. Complex 1 has a 3D supramolecular network constructed from 1D zigzag chain via π–π stacking interactions. Complex 2 features 1D ladder-like chain which consists of 1D helical arrays and bib pillars. Moreover, photoluminescence properties of the bib ligand and the Cd(II) complex were investigated.

KeywordsHydrothermal synthesisCoordination polymerManganese(ΙΙ)/cadmium(ΙΙ) complexespublisher-imprint-nameSpringervolume-issue-count6issue-article-count44issue-toc-levels0issue-pricelist-year2012issue-copyright-holderSpringer Science+Business Media, LLCissue-copyright-year2012article-contains-esmNoarticle-numbering-styleContentOnlyarticle-registration-date-year2011article-registration-date-month7article-registration-date-day16article-toc-levels0toc-levels0volume-typeRegularjournal-productNonStandardArchiveJournalnumbering-styleContentOnlyarticle-grants-typeRegularmetadata-grantOpenAccessabstract-grantOpenAccessbodypdf-grantRestrictedbodyhtml-grantRestrictedbibliography-grantRestrictedesm-grantOpenAccessonline-firstfalsepdf-file-referenceBodyRef/PDF/10904_2011_Article_9552.pdftarget-typeOnlinePDFissue-online-date-year2012issue-online-date-month1issue-online-date-day22issue-print-date-year2012issue-print-date-month1issue-print-date-day21issue-typeRegulararticle-typeBriefCommunicationjournal-subject-primaryChemistryjournal-subject-secondaryInorganic Chemistryjournal-subject-secondaryOrganic Chemistryjournal-subject-secondaryPolymer Sciencesjournal-subject-collectionChemistry and Materials Scienceopen-accessfalseIntroduction

The construction of functional solids based on metal–organic coordination polymers has received great interest recently due to its potential applications in luminescence, magnetism, catalysis and adsorption [1–12]. Carboxylate-containing ligands usually adopt diverse coordination modes such as monodentate, bis-monodentate, bridging bidentate to two metal atoms and chelation to one metal. Thus, a large number of metal–organic frameworks (MOF) based on carboxylate ligands, which are designed to give 1D chains to 3D frameworks, have been rapidly expanding area of research. To our knowledge, the studies of coordination polymers based on oxo-bridged carboxylate ligands are rare [13–18]. In the communication, 2-(3-carboxyphenoxy)benzoic acid and N-donor ligands were used to construct two new metal coordination polymers, [Mn(oba)·(2,2′-bipy)]n (1) and {[Cd(oba)(bib)]·H2O}n (2).

ExperimentalGeneral Materials and Method

All reagent and solvents employed were commercially available from the Jinan Henghua Sci. & Tec. Co. Ltd. and used as received without further purification; the purity of all reagents is 98%. Elemental analysis was carried out on a Carlo Erba 1106 full-automatic trace organic elemental analyzer. Fourier transform infrared spectra (FT-IR) were recorded with a Bruker Equinox 55 FT-IR spectrometer as a dry KBr pellet from 400 to 4000 cm−1. Solid-state fluorescence spectra were recorded at room temperature on a F-4600 equipped with a xenon lamp and a quartz carrier.

Synthesis[Mn(oba)(2,2′-bipy)]<sub><italic>n</italic></sub>

The hydrothermal reaction involving MnCl2·4H2O (0.198 g; 1 mmol), H2oba (0.242 g; 1 mmol), 2,2′-bipy (0.156 g; 1 mmol), NaOH (0.08 g; 2 mmol) and distilled water (18 mL) was carried out in a sealed 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel and heated at 160 °C for 96 h. After cooling to room temperature, yellow block crystals were obtained, which were washed with alcohol several times; (yield, 57% based on Mn). Elemental Anal. Calcd. (%) for C24H16MnN(2)O(5) : C, 61.68; H, 3.45; N, 5.99 . Found: C, 61.49; H, 3.42; N, 5.92. IR (cm−1): 1646s, 1568s, 1483s, 1364w, 974m, 748m, 681w, 573m.

{[Cd(oba)(bib)]·H<sub>2</sub>O}<sub><italic>n</italic></sub>

A mixture of Cd(OAc)2·2H2O (0.267 g; 1 mmol), H2oba (0.242 g; 1 mmol), bib (0.218 g; 1 mmol), NaOH (0.08 g; 2 mmol) and deionized water (18 mL) was sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel and heated at 160 °C for 96 h. After cooling to room temperature, colorless block crystals were obtained, which were washed with alcohol several times; yield, 45% based on Cd. Elemental Anal. Calcd. (%) for C36H32CdN4O6 : C, 59.31; H, 4.42; N, 7.68. Found: C, 59.18; H, 4.39; N, 7.67. IR (cm−1): 1622s, 1577s, 1462s, 1120w, 947w, 833m, 761m, 626w, 537w.

X-ray Crystallography

Diffraction intensity data of a single crystal of the two compounds were collected on a Bruker SMART APEXII CCD diffractometer equipped with a graphite monochromated Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) using a ω-scan mode. Empirical absorption correction was applied using the SADABS programs [19]. All the structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods on F2 using the program SHEXL-97 [20]. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms were located by geometric calculations and the positions and thermal parameters were fixed during the structural refinement. The crystallographic data and experimental details of structural analyses for 1 and 2 are summarized in Table 1. Selected bond and angle parameters are listed in Table 2.

Results and DiscussionsX-ray Diffraction Analyses[Mn(oba)(2,2′-bipy)]<sub><italic>n</italic></sub> (1)

Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that 1 crystallizes in the triclinic structure with space group (P − 1). Each Mn(II) atom is hexa-coordinated with a distorted octahedral geometry by four oxygen atoms to three different oba2− ligands [d(Mn–O) ranges from 2.0928(17) to 2.4314(17) Å] and two nitrogen atoms from one 2,2′-bipy ligand [d(Mn(1)–N(1)) = 2.990(18) Å and d(Mn(1)–N(2)0 = 2.2913(18) Å] (Fig. 1a). The carboxylic groups of oba2− adopt bis-monodentate and chelating bidentate modes. Each pair of Mn(II) ions are bridged by two carboxylate groups to generate an eight-member ring, which forms a 1D zigzag chain. The Mn–Mn separation in the ring is 4.1686 Å (Fig. 1b).

The 2,2′-bipy ligands are alternately attached to both sides of the 1D chain, providing potential supramolecular recognition sites for π–π stacking interactions. The interchain distance between parallel 1,10-phen ligands are ca. 3.467 Å and the corresponding centroid-to-centroid distance is ca. 3.668 Å. There also exits π–π stacking between the phenyl rings of the oba2− and 1,10-phen ligands with centroid-to-centroid distance of 3.974 Å (Fig. 1c). Intermolecular π–π stacking interactions further assemble the 1D chains to form a 3D supramolecular framework (Fig. 1d).

{[Cd(oba)(bib)]·H<sub>2</sub>O}<sub><italic>n</italic></sub> (2)

The local coordination and geometry of the polymer 2 with atomic numbering scheme is depicted in Fig. 2a. The asymmetry unit of the molecule consists of one Cd(II) ion, two coordinated oba2− ligands and two bib ligands. The bond lengths and bond angles are given in Table 2. Cd(II) ion is surrounded by four oxygen atoms from oba2− ligands [Distances: Cd(1)–O(1) = 2.310(4), Cd(1)–O(2) = 2.433(4), Cd(1)–O(4) = 2.518(4) and Cd(1)–O(5) = 2.284(4) Å] and two nitrogen atoms from two bib ligands [d(Cd(1)–N(1)) = 2.234(5) and d(Cd(1)–N(3)) = 2.268(4) Å] with octahedral coordination. Two carboxylate groups of oba2− adopt a chelating bidentate mode. The adjacent Cd(II) ions are bridged by V-shaped oba2− ligands to form a helical chain b-axis (Fig. 2(b)). The helix is generated around the crystallographic 21 axis with a pitch of 9.1781 Å. The adjacent meso-helical chains interact into 1D ladder-like chain parallel to the bc plane through a bib connection of ligands (Fig. 2c).

Photoluminescent Properties

Compound 2 and the bib ligand exhibit fluorescent emission bands at 375 nm (λex = 317 nm) and 332 nm (λex = 284 nm) (Fig. 3). The photoluminescence (PL) property of the free H2oba ligand displays weak luminescence at ca. 345 nm (λex = 280 nm) [18]. The shift of the PL emission bands in 2 is probably due to the cooperative effects of intra-ligand emission and ligand-to-metal charge transfer [21, 22]. Moreover, the violet–blue PL emission can be attributed to the presence of shallow defects within the band-gap that, after excitation, leads to a recombination process between electrons and holes in the defects lattice present in the triclinic and monoclinic structure [23–25]. Thus the title compounds may well be excellent candidates for blue fluorescent materials.

Conclusions

Oxo-bridged carboxylate and N-donor ligands were used to construct two new metal-coordination polymers of Mn(II) and Cd(II). X-ray analyses reveals that both complexes demonstrate a one-dimension structure. Moreover, solid-state luminescence of the Cd(II) polymer indicates that it is a good candidate for optical materials.

Supplementary Materials

Crystallographic data for the structural analysis have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center, CCDC reference numbers: 794284 and 819882. These data can be obtained free of charge at: http://www.ccdc.cam.ac.UK (or Cambridge crystallographic Data Center, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, UK (fax: +44-1223-336-033; e-mail: eposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk).

elements.content: Two new metal–organic coordination polymers containing Mn(II) and Cd(II) with oxo-bridged and N-donor ligands, [Mn(oba)(2,2′-bipy)]n (1) and {[Cd(oba)(bib)]·H2O}n (2) [2,3′-H2oba = 2-(3-carboxyphenoxy)benzoic acid, 2,2′-bipy = 2,2′-bipyridine, and bib = 4,4′-bis(2-methylimidazole-1-ylmethyl)biphenyl], have been prepared and characterized by elemental analysis, Fourier infrared spectroscopy, and X-ray diffraction. Complex 1 has a 3D supramolecular network constructed from 1D zigzag chain via π–π stacking interactions. Complex 2 features 1D ladder-like chain which consists of 1D helical arrays and bib pillars. Moreover, photoluminescence properties of the bib ligand and the Cd(II) complex were investigated.
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Two new metal-organic coordination polymers containing Mn(II) and Cd(II) with oxo-bridged and N-donor ligands, [Mn(oba)(2,2'-bipy)]n (1) and {[Cd(oba)(bib)]⋅H2O}n (2) [2,3'-H2oba = 2-(3-carboxyphenoxy)benzoic acid, 2,2'-bipy = 2,2'-bipyridine, and bib = 4,4'-bis(2-methylimidazole-1-ylmethyl)biphenyl], have been prepared and characterized by elemental analysis, Fourier infrared spectroscopy, and X-ray diffraction. Complex 1 has a 3D supramolecular network constructed from 1D zigzag chain via π-π stacking interactions. Complex 2 features 1D ladder-like chain which consists of 1D helical arrays and bib pillars. Moreover, photoluminescence properties of the bib ligand and the Cd(II) complex were investigated.

elements.content: The construction of functional solids based on metal–organic coordination polymers has received great interest recently due to its potential applications in luminescence, magnetism, catalysis and adsorption [1–12]. Carboxylate-containing ligands usually adopt diverse coordination modes such as monodentate, bis-monodentate, bridging bidentate to two metal atoms and chelation to one metal. Thus, a large number of metal–organic frameworks (MOF) based on carboxylate ligands, which are designed to give 1D chains to 3D frameworks, have been rapidly expanding area of research. To our knowledge, the studies of coordination polymers based on oxo-bridged carboxylate ligands are rare [13–18]. In the communication, 2-(3-carboxyphenoxy)benzoic acid and N-donor ligands were used to construct two new metal coordination polymers, [Mn(oba)·(2,2′-bipy)]n (1) and {[Cd(oba)(bib)]·H2O}n (2).
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The construction of functional solids based on metal-organic coordination polymers has received great interest recently due to its potential applications in luminescence, magnetism, catalysis and adsorption [1-12]. Carboxylate-containing ligands usually adopt diverse coordination modes such as monodentate, bis-monodentate, bridging bidentate to two metal atoms and chelation to one metal. Thus, a large number of metal-organic frameworks (MOF) based on carboxylate ligands, which are designed to give 1D chains to 3D frameworks, have been rapidly expanding area of research. To our knowledge, the studies of coordination polymers based on oxo-bridged carboxylate ligands are rare [13-18]. In the communication, 2-(3-carboxyphenoxy)benzoic acid and N-donor ligands were used to construct two new metal coordination polymers, [Mn(oba)⋅(2,2'-bipy)]n (1) and {[Cd(oba)(bib)]⋅H2O}n (2).

elements.content: All reagent and solvents employed were commercially available from the Jinan Henghua Sci. & Tec. Co. Ltd. and used as received without further purification; the purity of all reagents is 98%. Elemental analysis was carried out on a Carlo Erba 1106 full-automatic trace organic elemental analyzer. Fourier transform infrared spectra (FT-IR) were recorded with a Bruker Equinox 55 FT-IR spectrometer as a dry KBr pellet from 400 to 4000 cm−1. Solid-state fluorescence spectra were recorded at room temperature on a F-4600 equipped with a xenon lamp and a quartz carrier.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

General Materials and Method

All reagent and solvents employed were commercially available from the Jinan Henghua Sci. & Tec. Co. Ltd. and used as received without further purification; the purity of all reagents is 98%. Elemental analysis was carried out on a Carlo Erba 1106 full-automatic trace organic elemental analyzer. Fourier transform infrared spectra (FT-IR) were recorded with a Bruker Equinox 55 FT-IR spectrometer as a dry KBr pellet from 400 to 4000 cm-1. Solid-state fluorescence spectra were recorded at room temperature on a F-4600 equipped with a xenon lamp and a quartz carrier.

elements.content: The hydrothermal reaction involving MnCl2·4H2O (0.198 g; 1 mmol), H2oba (0.242 g; 1 mmol), 2,2′-bipy (0.156 g; 1 mmol), NaOH (0.08 g; 2 mmol) and distilled water (18 mL) was carried out in a sealed 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel and heated at 160 °C for 96 h. After cooling to room temperature, yellow block crystals were obtained, which were washed with alcohol several times; (yield, 57% based on Mn). Elemental Anal. Calcd. Synthesis

[Mn(oba)(2,2'-bipy)]n

The hydrothermal reaction involving MnCl2⋅4H2O (0.198 g; 1 mmol), H2oba (0.242 g; 1 mmol), 2,2'-bipy (0.156 g; 1 mmol), NaOH (0.08 g; 2 mmol) and distilled water (18 mL) was carried out in a sealed 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel and heated at 160 °C for 96 h. After cooling to room temperature, yellow block crystals were obtained, which were washed with alcohol several times; (yield, 57% based on Mn). Elemental Anal. Calcd. (%) for C24H16MnN(2)O(5) : C, 61.68; H, 3.45; N, 5.99 . Found: C, 61.49; H, 3.42; N, 5.92. IR (cm-1): 1646s, 1568s, 1483s, 1364w, 974m, 748m, 681w, 573m.

elements.content: Diffraction intensity data of a single crystal of the two compounds were collected on a Bruker SMART APEXII CCD diffractometer equipped with a graphite monochromated Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) using a ω-scan mode. Empirical absorption correction was applied using the SADABS programs [19]. All the structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods on F2 using the program SHEXL-97 [20]. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms were located by geometric calculations and the positions and thermal parameters were fixed during the structural refinement. The crystallographic data and experimental details of structural analyses for 1 and 2 are summarized in Table 1. Selected bond and angle parameters are listed in Table 2.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

Diffraction intensity data of a single crystal of the two compounds were collected on a Bruker SMART APEXII CCD diffractometer equipped with a graphite monochromated Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) using a ω-scan mode. Empirical absorption correction was applied using the SADABS programs [19]. All the structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods on F2 using the program SHEXL-97 [20]. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms were located by geometric calculations and the positions and thermal parameters were fixed during the structural refinement. The crystallographic data and experimental details of structural analyses for 1 and 2 are summarized in Table 1. Selected bond and angle parameters are listed in Table 2.

Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that 1 crystallizes in the triclinic structure with space group (P − 1). Each Mn(II) atom is hexa-coordinated with a distorted octahedral geometry by four oxygen atoms to three different oba2− ligands [d(Mn–O) ranges from 2.0928(17) to 2.4314(17) Å] and two nitrogen atoms from one 2,2′-bipy ligand [d(Mn(1)–N(1)) = 2.990(18) Å and d(Mn(1)–N(2)0 = 2.2913(18) Å] (Fig. 1a). The carboxylic groups of oba2− adopt bis-monodentate and chelating bidentate modes. Each pair of Mn(II) ions are bridged by two carboxylate groups to generate an eight-member ring, which forms a 1D zigzag chain. The Mn–Mn separation in the ring is 4.1686 Å (Fig. 1b).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussions

X-ray Diffraction Analyses

[Mn(oba)(2,2'-bipy)]n (1)

Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that 1 crystallizes in the triclinic structure with space group (P - 1). Each Mn(II) atom is hexa-coordinated with a distorted octahedral geometry by four oxygen atoms to three different oba2- ligands [d(Mn-O) ranges from 2.0928(17) to 2.4314(17) Å] and two nitrogen atoms from one 2,2'-bipy ligand [d(Mn(1)-N(1)) = 2.990(18) Å and d(Mn(1)-N(2)0 = 2.2913(18) Å] (Fig. 1a). The carboxylic groups of oba2- adopt bis-monodentate and chelating bidentate modes. Each pair of Mn(II) ions are bridged by two carboxylate groups to generate an eight-member ring, which forms a 1D zigzag chain. The Mn-Mn separation in the ring is 4.1686 Å (Fig. 1b).

elements.content: The 2,2′-bipy ligands are alternately attached to both sides of the 1D chain, providing potential supramolecular recognition sites for π–π stacking interactions. The interchain distance between parallel 1,10-phen ligands are ca. 3.467 Å and the corresponding centroid-to-centroid distance is ca. 3.668 Å. There also exits π–π stacking between the phenyl rings of the oba2− and 1,10-phen ligands with centroid-to-centroid distance of 3.974 Å (Fig. 1c). Intermolecular π–π stacking interactions further assemble the 1D chains to form a 3D supramolecular framework (Fig. 1d).

The interchain distance between parallel 1,10-phen ligands are ca. 3.467 Å and the corresponding centroid-to-centroid distance is ca. 3.668 Å. There also exits π-π stacking between the phenyl rings of the oba2- and 1,10-phen ligands with centroid-to-centroid distance of 3.974 Å (Fig. 1c). Intermolecular π-π stacking interactions further assemble the 1D chains to form a 3D supramolecular framework (Fig. 1d).

elements.content: The local coordination and geometry of the polymer 2 with atomic numbering scheme is depicted in Fig. 2a. The asymmetry unit of the molecule consists of one Cd(II) ion, two coordinated oba2− ligands and two bib ligands. The bond lengths and bond angles are given in Table 2. Cd(II) ion is surrounded by four oxygen atoms from oba2− ligands [Distances: Cd(1)–O(1) = 2.310(4), Cd(1)–O(2) = 2.433(4), Cd(1)–O(4) = 2.518(4) and Cd(1)–O(5) = 2.284(4) Å] and two nitrogen atoms from two bib ligands [d(Cd(1)–N(1)) = 2.234(5) and d(Cd(1)–N(3)) = 2.268(4) Å] with octahedral coordination. Two carboxylate groups of oba2− adopt a chelating bidentate mode. The adjacent Cd(II) ions are bridged by V-shaped oba2− ligands to form a helical chain b-axis (Fig. 2(b)). The helix is generated around the crystallographic 21 axis with a pitch of 9.1781 Å. The adjacent meso-helical chains interact into 1D ladder-like chain parallel to the bc plane through a bib connection of ligands (Fig. 2c).

{[Cd(oba)(bib)]⋅H2O}n (2)

The local coordination and geometry of the polymer 2 with atomic numbering scheme is depicted in Fig. 2a. The asymmetry unit of the molecule consists of one Cd(II) ion, two coordinated oba2- ligands and two bib ligands. The bond lengths and bond angles are given in Table 2. Cd(II) ion is surrounded by four oxygen atoms from oba2- ligands [Distances: Cd(1)-O(1) = 2.310(4), Cd(1)-O(2) = 2.433(4), Cd(1)-O(4) = 2.518(4) and Cd(1)-O(5) = 2.284(4) Å] and two nitrogen atoms from two bib ligands [d(Cd(1)-N(1)) = 2.234(5) and d(Cd(1)-N(3)) = 2.268(4) Å] with octahedral coordination. Two carboxylate groups of oba2- adopt a chelating bidentate mode. The adjacent Cd(II) ions are bridged by V-shaped oba2- ligands to form a helical chain b-axis (Fig. 2(b)). The helix is generated around the crystallographic 21 axis with a pitch of 9.1781 Å. The adjacent meso-helical chains interact into 1D ladder-like chain parallel to the bc plane through a bib connection of ligands (Fig. 2c).

elements.content: Compound 2 and the bib ligand exhibit fluorescent emission bands at 375 nm (λex = 317 nm) and 332 nm (λex = 284 nm) (Fig. 3). The photoluminescence (PL) property of the free H2oba ligand displays weak luminescence at ca. 345 nm (λex = 280 nm) [18]. The shift of the PL emission bands in 2 is probably due to the cooperative effects of intra-ligand emission and ligand-to-metal charge transfer [21, 22]. Moreover, the violet–blue PL emission can be attributed to the presence of shallow defects within the band-gap that, after excitation, leads to a recombination process between electrons and holes in the defects lattice present in the triclinic and monoclinic structure [23–25]. Thus the title compounds may well be excellent candidates for blue fluorescent materials.
elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescent Properties

Compound 2 and the bib ligand exhibit fluorescent emission bands at 375 nm (λex = 317 nm) and 332 nm (λex = 284 nm) (Fig. 3). The photoluminescence (PL) property of the free H2oba ligand displays weak luminescence at ca. 345 nm (λex = 280 nm) [18]. The shift of the PL emission bands in 2 is probably due to the cooperative effects of intra-ligand emission and ligand-to-metal charge transfer [21, 22]. Moreover, the violet-blue PL emission can be attributed to the presence of shallow defects within the band-gap that, after excitation, leads to a recombination process between electrons and holes in the defects lattice present in the triclinic and monoclinic structure [23-25]. Thus the title compounds may well be excellent candidates for blue fluorescent materials.

elements.content: Oxo-bridged carboxylate and N-donor ligands were used to construct two new metal-coordination polymers of Mn(II) and Cd(II). X-ray analyses reveals that both complexes demonstrate a one-dimension structure. Moreover, solid-state luminescence of the Cd(II) polymer indicates that it is a good candidate for optical materials.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Oxo-bridged carboxylate and N-donor ligands were used to construct two new metal-coordination polymers of Mn(II) and Cd(II). X-ray analyses reveals that both complexes demonstrate a one-dimension structure. Moreover, solid-state luminescence of the Cd(II) polymer indicates that it is a good candidate for optical materials.

cln_elements.content: Compound 2 and the bib ligand exhibit fluorescent emission bands at 375 nm (λex = 317 nm) and 332 nm (λex = 284 nm) (Fig. 3). The photoluminescence (PL) property of the free H2oba ligand displays weak luminescence at ca. 345 nm (λex = 280 nm) [18]. The shift of the PL emission bands in 2 is probably due to the cooperative effects of intra-ligand emission and ligand-to-metal charge transfer [21, 22]. Moreover, the violet–blue PL emission can be attributed to the presence of shallow defects within the band-gap that, after excitation, leads to a recombination process between electrons and holes in the defects lattice present in the triclinic and monoclinic structure [23–25]. Thus the title compounds may well be excellent candidates for blue fluorescent materials.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescent Properties

Compound 2 and the bib ligand exhibit fluorescent emission bands at 375 nm (λex = 317 nm) and 332 nm (λex = 284 nm) (Fig. 3). The photoluminescence (PL) property of the free H2oba ligand displays weak luminescence at ca. 345 nm (λex = 280 nm) [18]. The shift of the PL emission bands in 2 is probably due to the cooperative effects of intra-ligand emission and ligand-to-metal charge transfer [21, 22]. Moreover, the violet-blue PL emission can be attributed to the presence of shallow defects within the band-gap that, after excitation, leads to a recombination process between electrons and holes in the defects lattice present in the triclinic and monoclinic structure [23-25]. Thus the title compounds may well be excellent candidates for blue fluorescent materials.
